# Titolo: La Traduzione come Arte

## Introduzione

La traduzione è un'arte raffinata che richiede non solo una profonda conoscenza delle lingue, ma anche una sensibilità culturale e una maestria linguistica. In questo viaggio attraverso le parole, ci immergiamo nell'affascinante mondo della traduzione italiana-inglese, esplorando le sfumature e le sfide che esso presenta.

## La Sfida della Traduzione

Tradurre non è semplicemente sostituire parole da una lingua all'altra. È un processo complesso che coinvolge la comprensione del contesto, la cattura dell'essenza del testo originale e la sua riproduzione in una nuova lingua con fedeltà e grazia. L'italiano, con la sua ricchezza di espressioni idiomatiche e la sua musicalità, presenta sfide uniche per il traduttore.

## Adattare e Preservare

L'obiettivo principale di un traduttore è di adattare il testo alla nuova lingua, preservando al contempo il suo significato e il suo impatto originale. Questo richiede una scelta attenta delle parole, una comprensione delle strutture grammaticali e una sensibilità per le differenze culturali. La traduzione deve fluire naturalmente, come se fosse stata scritta nella lingua di destinazione fin dall'inizio.

## Esplorare le Sfumature

La lingua italiana è nota per le sue sfumature e sottigliezze. Espressioni come "fare una passeggiata" (che implica un'azione rilassata) e "andare a spasso" (che suggerisce un movimento più casuale) richiedono una traduzione attenta per catturare la sfumatura di significato. Il traduttore deve essere un artista, dipingendo con parole per evocare la stessa atmosfera e emozioni del testo originale.

## Conclusione

La traduzione italiana-inglese è un'arte che richiede dedizione, competenza e una profonda comprensione di entrambe le culture. È un processo creativo che trasforma le parole, mantenendo intatta la loro essenza. Attraverso questa pratica, i traduttori diventano ponti tra culture, facilitando la comunicazione e arricchendo la nostra comprensione del mondo.

Therefore, it is of fundamental importance to have defined the role and competencies of these bodies, and to have granted them extensive powers, as it is the authorities' difficult task to oversee the common energy market.
Another element that was included during the trilogue is the exemption from common rules for so-called closed systems, namely airports, hospitals, stations, industrial sites, and the like.
Their specific beating hearts are subject to a more favorable regime, and this demonstrates the attention that the new directive gives to the needs of the European citizen.

In my view, the European citizen is the one who will truly benefit from this directive, as through the use of smart meters, they will have access to all information related to their bill and will be able to evaluate the best offer on the market and choose their own supplier.

Even though it is true that years will pass before we see the effects of this liberalization, it is nonetheless undeniable that the entry of new operators into the market will lead to a lowering of prices and more favorable market conditions for citizens of the Union.
Another important element is the recognition of European gas transmission network systems, which will ensure the security of gas supply to European citizens.
All of this also involves the reinforcement and creation of new infrastructure, such as distribution grids and storage facilities, which will be the driving force behind the third package.
Therefore, the opening of a competitive market is required to guarantee investments and long-term contracts by companies in the sector.
especially in the new member countries, where the creation of new infrastructures would also allow the resolution of centuries-old dependency issues.
Consumer protection for the most vulnerable has been taken into account, empowering national and regional authorities to ensure gas supply during the most critical periods.
The successful outcome of the gas directive, part of the entire energy package, once again highlights the role of Europe and its instructions for European citizens.

On one occasion, we find ourselves in this hall to defend a culinary, cultural, and rural heritage stemming from a centuries-old tradition, an invaluable asset that the world envies us for, representing an immense wealth for the economy and also for the identity of our union.

a heritage that today risks finding itself in serious difficulty due to the council committee's will to suppress the ban on cupage for the production of rosé wines, a will born under strong influences.

There, it will find its ratification without the possibility of intervention by the Parliament, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens, both producers and consumers, who will be affected by this initiative.

The committee proposes to allow the production of red wines by simply blending red and white wines, as do countries that do not possess our expertise and professionalism, under the mere pretext of meeting international competition.
As the convener of the inquiry, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our productions, the result of centuries of traditions and research, and significant investments of passion, is not an option.
Attention to detail in labeling is not the response we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this one, where the average consumer is undoubtedly more focused on price than on label text.

To counterbalance this decision, it would be sufficient to find a name for the new product and inform consumers about the existence of two different types of rosé, the different quality of the products, and the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of professionals in the sector.
Who will pay for all this?

The commission plans to implement any support programs in this regard, or will producers once again be left to pay the price after being asked to compete against low-cost competition in already extremely difficult times.
I hope that the council's committee is carefully making the right choice and, if necessary, will completely revise this procedure.
Madam President, honorable colleagues, first of all, I would like to greet the President of the DTP Party, Mr. Ahmet Turk, who is here with us in the Gallery of Honor and who is following the debate.
Dear Ahmet, know that we stand in solidarity with you, supporting the democratic struggle your party leads in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize the DTP as an indispensable tool for the promotion of democracy in Turkey, and for this reason, we firmly condemn the police operations that
Prime Minister Erdoğan has issued orders against you, imprisoning all three vice presidents of the DTP, along with over 300 activists and sympathizers.
The victory of the DTP in the recent local elections demonstrates that the DTP Party enjoys strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on President Erdogan to engage in direct discussions with the DTP, but his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, and more imprisonment.

Everyone is aware that my parliamentary group and the European Left have until now supported the process of Turkey's accession to the European Union, while also backing the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in these last two years and especially in recent months, Erdoğan has shown another face, that of a leader compromised with the worst elements of the Turkish army, who simply want to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling up with Kurds, and Erdoğan himself is closing any perspective of Turkey's accession.
It is solely your responsibility for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations and the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I intend to send a very strong political message: Erdogan must make the pursuit of a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish issue a priority, and this must be clear through direct negotiations with the DTP. Otherwise, we will be the ones to request the suspension of the accession negotiations with the European Union.

The path of Turkey's accession to the Union goes through the DTP and through dialogue, otherwise it will be us, that is, those who have until now supported the accession process, who will have to ask for a reflection period that risks being definitive.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, I would like to thank the Council for sharing the principles and above all, if you allow me, Commissioner Barroso, with whom I had a very fruitful dialogue that was extremely useful for the work we then brought to the House.

I would like to express my heartfelt thanks to the colleagues who worked on this report, providing me with ideas and, of course, contributing their vast experience. I am especially grateful to Mr. Demetriu, Baroness Ludford, and the excellent President Deré.
What Demetrio, Ladford, and Depre are saying is precisely that the most important thing, the real challenge for the European Union, is to achieve a unified European judicial culture.
while engaging in a serious battle over what Depre says, independence, justice, guarantees, and addressing the disparities of the various judicial systems are the challenges we face ahead.
But I believe that the work we have done allows us to be optimistic.

Mr. President, Mr. Csio, dear colleagues, it seems that the thousands of deaths we have seen so far due to asbestos, and the tens of thousands of victims,
people at risk of dying in the coming years due to past asbestos exposure—the latency period, we know, can reach 15 and even 20 years. Nothing continues absolutely.

It seems that the Etherite process begun in Turin regarding what happened in Casale Monferrato has not continued, where there is not a single family that has not experienced a bereavement within its ranks.
Asbestos should have been effectively banned by the Member States through the application of the directive of nineteen ninety.

States should have protected exposed workers with all possible precautions, implementing the 2003 directive, closing facilities, remediating contaminated sites, and compensating victims and affected populations.
This did not happen everywhere.
Little to nothing has been done.
I have already spoken about the Turin trial, where Swiss and Belgian owners are defendants.
Little was known, and mostly it was an industry that shirked its responsibilities, acting within the gaps of inertia and public authorities.
Examples of inertia can be seen, for instance, in Italy, in Brioni, where asbestos has not been removed, and in Porto Marghera, Cengio, where deaths are still being counted.
Today, the industry is asking the Commission to tolerate a further derogation already granted for a limited time by Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 for chrysotile asbestos fibres.

It is true that they have a limited application to low-voltage electrolysis plants and only in a few facilities, but where industry leaders claim impossibility, any alternative substitute would result in the closure of the plants.

blackmail, but an alternative to this process has been found in Sweden using technologies for the replacement of asbestos-free membranes for low voltage, and a similar solution has also been adopted for hydrogen production.
Why in some states yes and in others no?
Why, as in the long battle for the banning of PSB, have there been countless omissions and reticence, even endorsed by the Enterprise Directorate-General of the European Commission?
Even in this case, a poor example has been set.
The 1999 directive on the prohibition of asbestos required that the review of such authorization be preceded by an opinion from the Scientific Committee on Toxicology, which was never provided.
so that the committee adheres to the directives.
do not mention the union, which says it was not even consulted.
The European Parliament makes its own effort to keep pace with the extent of others.

This resolution calls on the commission to fill by 2009 a legislative gap regarding the banning of second-hand products containing asbestos, roof tiles, aircraft parts, and any other items that should be definitively disposed of.
They set precise dates once again for a strategy to ban all types of asbestos by 2015, but these were already goals written in 1999.
ten years have passed and he has continued to die.
The EU had claimed, among the first initiatives of this legislative term, the establishment of a community fund to compensate victims, and ad hoc funds for decontamination.
The request was specific to the commission, which today, however, yields to the will of multinationals.
It is necessary, instead, to move on to concrete commitment actions.
Only when these [points] stem from the very requests contained in this resolution, only then can we be understanding.
Today, this will is not evident, therefore we vote against the granting of the derogation.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, and I wanted to convey to President Buzek the pride that fills me at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament, which you preside over.
I believe that the sacrifices made by the people of your country over the past twenty years, which are now reflected in the twelve nations mentioned earlier in this assembly, will strengthen Europe.
However, I also want to express my concern after listening to your program as part of your speech, which should—and I hope it will—serve to strengthen this parliament.
I hope that what you have announced will come to pass.

I hope that the next President of the European Commission, surely President Barroso, will want to listen to her for the words she has spoken in order to ensure that this Parliament provides answers to more than

550 million citizens who voted for us in this Europe, who wanted and want and demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that Europe has certainly tried to provide but has not fully succeeded in giving.
In this endeavor, I place my hopes and I am certain that with her we will achieve the certainties she has promised us.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, it is not my intention, nor that of my group which has supported and requested this debate, to transfer attributes of Italian domestic policy to the European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns all of us and the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level in order to counter political and economic pressures and to guarantee genuine pluralism in information.

The Italian anomaly, where the prime minister also owns some of the most important private networks, lies precisely in the existence of a dangerous entanglement between media, political, and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, aims to protect media pluralism by preventing concentrations of ownership and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we call on the Commission to act as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Madam President, honorable colleagues, I am aware that on September 30th, the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report by rapporteur Marianne Mikko was adopted, in which the European Commission and Member States were urged to protect, I quote, "the multiplicity" [of media voices].
of opinions in the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to ensure that all European Union citizens have equal access to free and diverse media.

even before that, in 2004, a rapporteur's report by Bogert was voted on in Parliament concerning the risks of violations in the European Union of freedom of expression and information, in which the Commission was asked to present a communication on guaranteeing media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear responses to the Parliament's requests.

You will notice, Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country or my Prime Minister, but as a European citizen, I ask you here what the Commission intends to do at European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Mr. President, given that the discussion regarding the vote that took place yesterday in the Environment Committee has been raised several times.

Science, as a totem, does not exist. When one makes the mistake of identifying a problem in such an ideological manner, it does not provide answers but rather creates them.
Disasters and Europe, in this regard, it should be a master and not repeat the same mistakes, even if in different guises and with labels that appear superficially much more friendly.

I must recall that the same emission trading directive specifically provides for the virtuous path of the European Union to be subject to an evaluation by the Commission based on the outcomes of the conference.

These are fundamental points. We want the Chiotto protocol itself to retain its environmental significance, and above all, we want to prevent the creation of a financial bubble at the expense of our European businesses.
Very important for two reasons: the first is the research topic concerning the fight against neurodegenerative diseases, and the second is the method of joint programming in research.
We would have obviously preferred, as has been stated and is the subject of our inquiry, a more direct involvement of the Parliament in the pilot project.

If we must now proceed without pausing, we nonetheless request assurances that our opinion will be taken into consideration in the implementation of the Competitiveness Council's recommendations, and that a more legally sound and certain foundation be established for the future, ensuring full involvement of the Parliament and fuller ownership in this area of research.

Now we must intervene with appropriate means and resources to prevent and eradicate a scourge as widespread as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and other diseases that are destined to increase with the aging of the population.
We call for a focus on large-scale, comprehensive studies, aimed at both diagnosis and the identification of treatments.

Fundamental seem to be the researches on biomarkers, on early diagnosis methods based on a multidisciplinary approach, the establishment of extensive databases, the search for curative drugs, and the development of care models and appropriate services.

I feel compelled to make only one request in this context: that the subjectivity of patients, too often excluded in this type of disease, and the involvement of associations, patients, and relatives, be not overlooked.
From a methodological standpoint, we believe joint research projects to be highly significant as they address a fundamental need: the concentration of efforts and resources.
overcome those fragmentations, those duplications, and thus be able to create a critical mass sufficient to yield adequate outcomes for this type of research.

When we consider that in other areas of the world, joint public and private efforts result in investments of tens of millions of euros, we realize how much remains to be done and how much we must do, converging on projects.

shared across strategic lines and shared programs between States and Europe, and on common programs between public and private entities, without neglecting that international framework that connects us to the major scientific realities at the international level.
The novelties of the Stockholm program compared to that of The Hague lie in a fair balance between rights and security, and in legal protection in both criminal and civil fields.

Safety is a right: not to be assaulted in one's workplace, to walk the streets without risking one's life, not to be subjected to violence because one is a woman, not to be exposed to acts of terrorism.
States and Europe must ensure security.
But a security measure that weakens guarantees of freedom is a measure that undermines the certainty of law and is thus a source of insecurity and barbarity.
Guantanamo
Europe is the homeland of rights.
The Stockholm program defines them as a collection of details.

Today, a fair balance between the discipline of crime suppression on the one hand and the daily life of citizens and their family, social, economic, work, and study relationships, all regulated by civil law and civil justice.
This is the Europe of the citizen.
It is constructed within states and community institutions.
European society is more united, and mobility is more intense than one might think.
Bubbliness is now a right.
The borders between states are not impenetrable walls, they are nets through which society filters every day.
Stockholm provides the institutional framework, judicial cooperation, mutual recognition, and a European justice, distinct from the national one.
It is the community one, a European, national, and community right, a European citizen, a European judge, both the national and the community one.

European rules are dictated by community regulations and the jurisprudence of the European courts, but also stem from the behaviors of workers, businesses, students, national magistrates, and European networks among justice professionals.
This map, then, and this bottom-up process is what the Stockholm program wants to support.
The Parliament has made a great effort with this resolution, which I hope will be supported here by a broad, unanimous vote that we have worked intensively on.

Lisbon is not yet in force, but it is there, very much present.
Let the Council be ambitious, Madam Minister, make the most of what we have developed here and the wealth of insights that emerge from it.
In the budget control, I must acknowledge the very important work carried out by the committee, the excellent work of the rapporteur, and I must also mention the political unity.

This is because from the very beginning we have wanted to send a very clear message: we intend to work with great rigor to ensure transparency, correctness, and legality in the management of public funds and, consequently, in the verification of budgets.
Very significant steps have been taken with the Council, which initially did not want to respond.
I personally acknowledge the Swedish presidency, which has always sought to demonstrate its commitment to transparency and fairness.
So we expect further progress from this perspective because it is absolutely unacceptable, especially with the entry into force of the treaty.

It is concerning that Parliament does not have access to information and data specifically to audit budgets and public funds, in the interest not only of the European Union but also of all European citizens.
Mr. President, we were gathered when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the peace process in the Middle East.
We have witnessed the smile of hope on the faces of the Palestinian representatives.
These were intense days of emotions and sufferings, etched onto the faces of children clinging to the window grates of their homes, on Hebron Street, the ghost road that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman evicted from her home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent pitched in the garden of what had been her house, the suffering etched on the faces of those Palestinians who, with European funding, had built a farm later destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, a passport.
The decision by the Council of Europe represents a significant step forward, but action must be taken immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the final day and during the visit, the Israeli authorities prevented us, the European Parliament delegation, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this matter, High Representative Baroness Ashton should intervene to voice the protest of democratic Europe.

Ladies and Gentlemen, let me express my gratitude to President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all its other members. During our stay in Palestine, the vulnerable people of Palestine were able to see and hear the face and the words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Madam/Sir, honorable colleagues, the European Union is committed to the fight against terrorism in all its dimensions.

When discussing the fight against terrorist offenses, it is essential to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures adopted to combat terrorism are appropriate and effective.
The right to defense and fundamental procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the Union's institutions, even when they draw up lists of identified persons in this case linked to...
subject to restrictive measures, and it is equally essential that these measures are subject to appropriate democratic and parliamentary scrutiny, as rightly prescribed by the Treaty of Lisbon.

It is therefore evident that, as also stated by the Legal Service of the Parliament, any measure of this kind must follow the co-decision procedure, allowing representatives of European citizens to fully exercise their legislative and oversight role.
Madam President, I would like to avoid continuing to list the reasons for our dissent with the Iranian government.
I would like to emphasize, since it was not mentioned here, one of the most serious facts in the violation of civil rights, which is the one perpetrated against young people.
Having also signed the United Nations Treaty on the Rights of the Child, the Iranian government continues to impose capital punishment on minors.
I would like, following this debate, for Baroness Ashton to commit to outlining a common line for all of Europe and the whole Parliament.
on the developments in Iran and, on the other hand, that the Interparliamentary Commission with the Government of Iran acknowledges that it has changed its course of action.

I participated with friends Scuriia and Tatarella in the protest we had organized against the Commission, which, nevertheless, through an official statement, declared its intention to go to Iran. We had instead categorically requested that there be an opportunity to meet with the opposition and engage in dialogue with them.

I would like the Commission, from this moment on, to turn over a new leaf and establish relations of aid, support, and dialogue with the representatives of the opposition in exile, not least Ms. Miriam Rajavi, who represents this reality.
the European Community should do this instead of imposing sanctions

Sir, I wish to draw attention to the severity of the deindustrialization situations facing several Sicilian industrial hubs, particularly the automotive sector in Termini Imerese, which is part of the Fiat group, and the petrochemical plant in Gela, belonging to the Eni group.
Immersed in a damaged market due to the competition stemming from the system of low wages within some European countries, GEO freezes Asian competition.
With regard to the severe deindustrialization processes that are occurring within vast areas of the Union, I believe it is time to reconsider the policy of non-intervention.
intervention so far adopted by the European Commission and to start implementing a package of measures to support relevant and strategic European industries.
This exhortation is primarily addressed to the European Commission and the Italian Csio (Central Service for Industrial Organizations).

Madam President, honorable colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, the topic of good fiscal governance, while always having been of great importance, has taken on even greater relevance following the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International summits, such as the G20 and European gatherings, have discussed and continue to debate these issues, especially when addressing the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.
All this is important, it is a sign of commitment and determination, but one must not delude oneself that an announcement is enough.
A serious and consistent policy is needed.
Many problems remain.
It is still far too easy to buy or set up a shell company to evade taxes.
A simple browse on the internet will suffice. There are thousands of websites offering companies for sale, even in European Union countries.
Often, it is sufficient to send an email with an attached scanned copy of the passport to be able to open a company.
The practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation must be put to an end.
This report that I present is based on the Communication from the European Commission on good fiscal governance of April 28, 2009.
The report is aimed at putting forward concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
The European Union must prioritize the fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and the illicit flight of capital.
From here stems the principle of good governance, based on transparency, information exchange, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that there is a growing need for fiscal cooperation and collaboration within the European Union.
The overall goal we should aim for is to achieve automatic information exchange on a global and multilateral scale, starting, of course, from the European Union.
As already stated by colleague Alvarez, we must completely abolish bank secrecy in European Union countries and put an end to the derogation regime without further delay.
temporary measure authorizing the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated in place of information exchange.
I do not intend to elaborate on the specific proposals contained in the report.
I emphasize that we still need, in particular, to: expand the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, combat VAT fraud, and establish a public register of the Union.
Take into account individuals or businesses that have established companies or opened accounts in tax havens, reconfirm and relaunch fiscal harmonization projects starting from there.

It is also necessary for the European Union to speak with one voice internationally, advocating for the improvement of OECD regulations to achieve automatic information exchange instead of exchange upon request.

Commissioner Kovacz, please also listen to the other relays. We need a strong commitment from the Commission, and at this moment, we need these priorities to be emphasized to the new Commission during the handover.
We will hold the Council and the Commission to account for the work.

European Parliament

I would like to thank my colleagues, and in particular the shadow rapporteurs, for their contributions to this work, which I hope will be approved by the Parliament.

Sir, I must admit that when we talk about counter-terrorism and discuss only intelligence and technology, I always get the impression that we are examining the issue inadequately, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing solely on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not high time to tackle the problem of terrorism, aiming at the core of the issue rather than merely focusing on its outward phenomenology?

Addressing the heart of the problem means, for instance, acknowledging that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or new unwillingness of certain groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I wonder, and I ask this Parliament, do we want to discuss terrorism.
Let this Parliament then have the courage to politically address a debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I have submitted a question to the Commission on the full scope of the issue to encourage this Assembly to openly confront the topic.
It appears that there is no intention to address the topic.
I wonder, and I ask my honorable colleagues from all political groups, if not on these issues, on what other topics should the political forum of the peoples of Europe express itself?
Madam President, honorable colleagues, concluding the negotiation with Croatia by 2010 is an achievable goal, and the Svoboda report balances the progress made with the steps still to be taken.
Now it is justice, the sector where significant reforms are still needed.
In fact, it is not enough to complete the necessary systemic reforms and adopt new laws, and to cooperate as necessary with the Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the need to create a genuine legal culture and mindset in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary becomes crucial, a central issue, along with the training, recruitment, and careers of judges. This includes the absence of various types of influence exerted by the government on judges.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the necessity of decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiation.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the accession of Croatia to the European Union underscores the consolidation of a European identity that can express the common values of the new Europe, while at the same time integrating, rather than eclipsing, the specific characteristics of its many constituent parts.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts in aligning itself with the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures. However, it needs to make further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Further steps can be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with the provisions of the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights, signed in Paris in 1952, by considering the restitution of nationalized property to its legitimate owners.
Mr. President, once again recently in Italy there has been an environmental disaster: the Lambro River and the Po River.

Recently, the Court of Justice in Luxembourg has convicted Italy for the danger to which public health is exposed due to the illegal disposal of waste and for its failure to control waste collection in Campania.
news of recent days about the increase in leukemias in Taranto through IVA (Value Added Tax), as well as asbestos disposal in schools in Crotone, and dioxin in Campania.
It is an ongoing environmental disaster.

I strongly urge the Commission to clarify its intentions regarding the measures it will take to bring the Italian government into line with European Union directive standards, particularly in light of the Court's ruling just the other day.

justice that has severely condemned Italy, which has failed to manage waste disposal in Campania. The city of Naples has been exposed to public ridicule for many weeks and for many months around the world.

This debate is not ritualistic, but aims to be very practical and to ask clear and precise questions about how many resources are needed and where they should be obtained. I hope that the Parliament expects equally clear and precise answers today and in the upcoming Councils on March 12th and 25th.

We firmly wish to tell the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised the flag of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge before the world, today has a duty of consistency, if it does not want to lose credibility.
You must do everything possible to ensure these goals are achieved.

We must be very well aware that talking about a low-carbon economy implies a sort of Copernican revolution for the productive system. This means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all, adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential if our productive system, European industry, is to remain competitive.
I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligences are ready, the capabilities exist, the will is there; now it is a matter of igniting this engine.
Everyone must do this, said the Commissioner, said the Council. It must be done by Member States, entrepreneurs, and private entities.
But I believe that the task is indispensable to bring together this complex partnership, which is also of the European Union.
To constructively address the employment issue, the three watchwords and community relations are: react, evolve, and protect.

To act, that is, to move away from the celebratory tones of Euro-propaganda to tackle in a concrete way the problems afflicting EU citizens, ensuring a direct link between the world of education and the needs of the market and the territory, and re-evaluating young people's perception of manual professions.

to evolve, that is, to make the 2020 web strategy a positive synthesis of the requests from businesses and workers, favoring a labor market where the flexibility and security of contractual forms respond to the instability of market demands.

Firstly, giving employment to those who have lost it, above all our citizens. Member states must therefore evaluate immigration policies based on the actual need for immigration, and with 23 million unemployed, the possibility of blocking non-EU immigration for a few years should be considered.
I see no other way to protect our work and our social system.
What is needed is practicality, courage, and decentralization.

President, this is an oral amendment to point 13, where it invites the commission to assess, in the current situation, the possibility of providing humanitarian aid, upon verification of the situation.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I would like to underscore once again the significance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed along with four other members of parliament and which a majority of the European Parliament has endorsed, thereby committing the Council and the Commission to introducing truly effective legislation on corruption.

I have returned, on behalf of the Budget Control Commission, from a visit to Greece, and certainly one of the reasons for Greece's structural crisis also depends on the waste of public funds, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

I run from corruption, as emerges these days, corruption that primarily circulates through the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a part of the political sphere and a part of the entrepreneurs, and the organized white-collar criminality.

It is important that the European Parliament exert all its pressure on the Commission and the Member States, that those Member States that do not comply be sanctioned, and that the European institutions responsible for controlling corruption and combating organized crime be strengthened.
For men and women, we are well aware that this difference is even more pronounced in the field of self-employed activities.
Indeed, women have all too often been forced to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of assuming the role or workload that stems from absolute dedication to the family.

To solve this problem, I believe it is necessary to implement measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but always keeping our eyes fixed on the pole star of the family; only thus can these measures acquire meaning and hope of success.

Freeing women from the anguishing dilemma of choosing between the roles of mother, wife, and entrepreneur means lightening the burden of family responsibilities and addressing the concrete issues through positive and specific measures of family support.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of bus passengers aims to enhance and safeguard passenger protection, particularly for persons with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should ensure that passengers are protected, just as is the case in the rail and air sectors.
The position in the second reading aims to establish a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I agree with the approach of rapporteur Cancian, whom I thank for the excellent work done, and believe that the scope of the regulation should be amended to exclude regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be fair and necessary to ensure the rights of passengers in the event of accidents, cancellations, or delays at departure, as had already been decided by the Parliament in its first reading.

Equally important is the issue of providing information on passenger rights. In fact, it would be useful to supply passengers with information about connections to other modes of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services by bus and by rail.

As for people with disabilities and reduced mobility, it is necessary to ensure the highest level of protection. I would propose reducing the time frame from 48 hours to 24 hours to request assistance, as well as stronger guarantees for compensation and replacement of the tools that ensure the mobility of people with disabilities in case of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructure improved to make it accessible.
This regulation aims to enhance the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all, to improve passenger travel conditions.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, I thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has done on this report, which addresses how to extend free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.

Harmonizing administrative procedures among Member States will facilitate smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and boost maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than ten percent of the total.

China has already been mentioned, but I would like to cite it here as well.
China allows itself, for example, an increase in its CO2 emissions of 5 billion tons by 2020, with consequences that could be offset.
It is perhaps not even, but only an attempt at compensation with a 100% reduction in European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This data not only renders the proposal for an unconditional 30% reduction, to which we strongly oppose, unrealistic, but it leads many independent observers to hypothesize nonetheless a significant increase in global emissions by that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least reckless and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and sketch out suggestive but unrealistic scenarios, where unknown variables inevitably impact the cost implications.

The hope is that the European Union brings to Cancun a shared, realistic, and sustainable proposal, because it is always and in any case preferable to have an agreement that yields tangible and perceptible results.

Colleagues, the discussion report certainly contains positive elements. The general orientation is towards simplifying procedures and reducing bureaucratic steps for workers from third countries with a regular residence permit in a member state.

However, as a point of reflection, I would like to remind you that today in Europe, tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are unemployed due to the structural shortcomings of the European production system and as a result of a crisis that seems never-ending.

Before even considering the needs of citizens from third countries residing in our nations, Europe should primarily focus on implementing economic, political, and social measures that first and foremost assist our citizens in finding or regaining employment.
If Europe can provide employment for its citizens, it will create solid social structures to adequately accommodate migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, first and foremost, to foster Europe's growth on its own two feet and with its own resources.
Our countries will then have the strength.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, to date, access to employment is regulated only for certain specific categories of citizens from third countries.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must act to ensure equal treatment for both third-country nationals legally residing within Member States and beneficiaries of refugee status or those in need of international protection, as per Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to prevent a growing demand, for example, for seasonal staff solely because they are paid less, or because they have different, lower costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same job.

One must avoid, for instance, the risk that many multinationals relocate their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees, and self-employed individuals are included in this directive.
Making differences will become extremely dangerous.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, according to estimates by international organizations and police bodies, human trafficking is now the second-largest source of profit globally for organized crime, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that approximately 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.
This means that, above all, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the security of our citizens, against clandestinity, and against crime that breeds crime.
Facing a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.

In combating this phenomenon, cooperation between member countries and between law enforcement agencies is necessary, but above all, there must be certainty of punishment for traffickers. However, it should be noted that many people are still falling victim.

They flee because in their countries of origin they do not find dignified living conditions; they live in poverty and despair and are willing to do anything to leave their land, driven by the promise of a better life that will not be fulfilled.

Europe, therefore, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit itself more diligently to ensure that these individuals can find acceptable living conditions in their own countries.

Acceptable. "Let's help them in their own countries" must be the guiding principle of European political action so that our efforts are directed not only towards repression but also towards prevention.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, the situation is that Campania, and in particular the city of Naples, are known worldwide, unfortunately, for this issue. The European Union has had to address the matter on multiple occasions.

Facing this now paradoxical third-world-like situation, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the perspective of Community law and what economic sanctions will potentially be imposed on Italy if the waste crisis in Campania does not find a definitive solution in the short term.

I further ask whether the Commission can provide in detail the data concerning the European funds that have so far been managed by the Campania region for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
Sir, Commissioner, usually when we speak of an emergency, we refer to extreme dramatic situations that, nevertheless, find solutions within reasonable timeframes.
When a so-called emergency has lasted for more than fifteen years, clearly something is not working.

The Italian government in recent years has endeavored to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of the waste collection and disposal cycle, but evidently, if today the streets of Naples are invaded by tons of waste, it is clear that much remains to be done.
In the midst of this waste crisis, the blame lies primarily with the local authorities in Campania and their total inability or lack of will to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear and absolutely beyond any doubt that the conditions in which the Campania region finds itself are due to the absence and negligence that have characterized municipalities, provinces, and regions for many years in the management of the waste cycle.
If the collection of recyclable materials, the first and indispensable element of a functioning waste management plan, is not enforced, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send the army, it was a few weeks ago, but also on other occasions in the past, to replace hundreds of garbage collectors who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill, it is evidently not the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while in the rest of Italy the situation is very different, for example in my region, Veneto, where separate collection has been carried out for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate, it means that the responsibilities for the emergency fall on...

on Campanian politics and local administrators, and above all on the heavy collusion with organized crime, which has always sought and obtained immense profits from the waste business through the infiltration of the Camorra into politics and local governments.
Does the Berlusconi government's lies, which in 2008 assured Italians that the waste problem had been resolved, do well to the European Union?

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, in my opinion, we have two problems here: one is methodological, and the other concerns the substance of the matter.

The method we are employing, for which we are grateful to the honorable Fraga, is an artifice: that of oral questions to discuss something that, after the Treaty of Lisbon, should be a right of this Parliament.
I believe this practice should end; we cannot resort to a strategy, for example, to accompany a co-decision process.

Today we are holding this debate, the treaty will be concluded, it will move forward, and we will say yes or no at the end.

In substance, however, I wished only to emphasize, agreeing with many points raised by my colleagues, the measurement of the effects of fisheries agreements, not because these are merely commercial agreements through which we go to buy cephalopods at one euro per kilogram in Mauritania.

These tools need to be able to measure both sustainability, but above all, the impact on that country's economy. They should assess the number of jobs that are transformed, understand the rate of innovation in artisanal fishing, and evaluate the utilization of these resources.
Not merely a straightforward commercial exchange, but rather a fishing agreement with all its implications.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, until today, the recommendations adopted by the General Commission for Fisheries and the Mediterranean have been provisionally incorporated into Community legislation through the annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
Those concerning conservation, management, exploitation, control, and marketing measures for fishery and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of these recommendations, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation and implementation within Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to incorporate the aforementioned recommendations through a single legislative act, to which future recommendations may be added.
Today we have done this, and this will improve legal certainty while also constituting an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGPM are obligated to ensure full implementation and agreed measures, effective from the high stability.

A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make these international measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at Community level and to ensure legal certainty and interaction.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I believe that the approval of the report by colleague Podima represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, advanced, and stronger economic and fiscal policy in the European field.

It is now evident to all the urgency for Europe, through coordination among the 27 countries, to equip itself with economic and financial tools capable of governing the economy and not merely enduring it.

The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this regulation is a significant milestone, because for the first time, inaction was not an option, and instead, a step forward was taken.
I hope that the commission and the council continue on this path.

I strongly support the reports on equality between men and women and on women's poverty in Europe, and I am pleased that this discussion is taking place today, on the centenary of International Women's Day.

The lack of access to care services for dependent individuals such as disabled children and elderly people, as well as adequate leave schemes and flexible work arrangements, prevents women from working.

Ladies and gentlemen, honorable colleagues, thanks to the Amsterdam Treaty, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained greater relevance and
Attention has focused on the integration of economic and environmental policies and on incorporating environmental issues into policies and other sectors.

Among the key sectors are climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, including the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusions, called on the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the key aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts should therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system capable of providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favor of this proposal to regulate the creation of new uses for national accounting data and environmental statistics, as well as other statistical sectors.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, the new Hungarian Constitution reduces the possibility of intervention by oversight bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive, thus calling into question the normal balance of powers.
Social rights are depleted; the state provides subsidies, and the needy only accept to perform public service jobs.
The right to self-defense is explicitly enshrined, allowing individuals to possess weapons in their homes even without a license.
It denies us the right to abortion and introduces strongly discriminatory rules towards homosexuals.
All of this is contrary to Directive 2000/78/EC, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to act, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are poorly compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

honorable members, the Fukushima accident continues to produce very serious consequences with the loss of radioactive water into the sea, 6,500 times the legal limits.
The risk that food products will become contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this concerns only fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly canned fish.
We import 370,000 tons of canned tuna, and the main suppliers are Southeast Asian countries, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe may contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the location where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and plans to address this gap through the reform of the common fisheries policy, which, however, will not enter into force for at least two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not take effect for three years.
We must not create alarmism, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The committee must intervene as soon as possible.

In the single market, the free movement of people and the Lisbon Treaty are all elements that have intervened regardless of a change in our way of legislating, both at the European and national levels.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, representative of the Council, and Commissioner, first of all, like other colleagues, I would also like to positively acknowledge the anti-corruption package that the European Commission adopted on June 6th.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures at the European level are necessary to combat it.
According to Eurobarometer estimates, the vast majority of our European citizens believe that Europe should do more.
How can one fault them?

In many Member States, there has been a lack of political will to combat corruption. Consider that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

When we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens' rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to combat it, adopted so far by the Member States, are insufficient to contain a phenomenon that is on the rise.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and strong response, especially now in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is weighing heavily on people's lives, on the sustainability of pension and welfare systems, and on the ability of institutions to ensure essential services.
Corruption causes an annual loss of 120 billion euros, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily diverts resources from the Union to its Member States.
should be used to provide essential services such as education, childcare, employment, transportation, in short, to divert clean resources away from supporting people, for the benefit of people.

Therefore, it is necessary to show more courage and firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by stepping up and strengthening the measures to combat corruption at EU level.

In particular, we cannot speak of fighting corruption if we are unable to adopt at least minimum rules for the definition of the crime of corruption, of which there is no trace in the recently approved package.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in member countries, essential for developing an effective response.
We are in favor, for example, of revitalizing the network of contact points of the twoE against corruption, as I proposed in the resolution we will vote on tomorrow.
is not a recent development; it has already existed for several years.

The Commission should overcome its weakness, state that the priority is fighting unemployment and creating jobs, redistributing wealth, and implementing a strategy of public investments, also changing the rules of the new European stability pact.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, European schools were established with the aim of ensuring access to education in one's mother tongue for the children of officials from European institutions who are called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their home country.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg in the distant year of 1953 at the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, given the positivity of this form of teaching, fourteen European schools have been established within the various member states.

While recognizing that the system of European schools represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that, more than 50 years after the creation of the first European school, this system may present obsolete aspects and must in some way be updated and adapted to new economic and social needs.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text by colleague Cavada, which aspires to greater involvement by the European Union to support and coordinate the actions of the Member States called upon to work towards developing and improving the system of European schools.
It is known that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans. Thank you, President.

Outline some key connections between European policies and this goal of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well, but often lacks consistency in its choices.

firstly, food supply, now at risk due to price volatility caused by speculation on food products, which needs to be contained if not prevented, including derivatives, etc.

thirdly, the coherence between energy supply and policies.

a purely political matter, as I believe it is necessary to bring the major issue of food security back to the center of the initiative of the entire European Union.

Sir, to the Commission. I really must thank all the people who have contributed over these weeks, these months to the production of this document that we are voting on in the Chamber today.

The numbers, when viewed in their raw form, are very eloquent. The number of disasters worldwide has quintupled if we consider that in 1975
There were 78 recorded catastrophic events, whereas today we are facing nearly 400 disastrous events per year.

In the last twenty years, unfortunately, the victims of these disasters have numbered 90, with over 29 million individuals affected by the disasters, while economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing one of those phenomena of such magnitude that it demands a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly robust commitment from us.
We all have in our minds the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, and what happened in Japan.
Europe itself experiences sudden floods, fires, and volcanic eruptions on its territory every year; we remember the ash cloud that followed the eruption of the Icelandic volcano.
There is a need to go further to affirm how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
The fundamentals that are our guiding stars, the principle of solidarity which is strengthened by the solidarity clause of the Treaty of Lisbon, and the principle of subsidiarity.

In the event that Bulgaria were to join the EU at this time, police and security agencies foresee that Bulgarian borders, especially maritime ones, would become easy targets for Turkish, Eastern European, and Bulgarian criminal organizations, and Romania and Bulgaria would become crossroads for human trafficking and drug smuggling.

It is natural that some Member States have significant reservations about Bulgaria's and Romania's actual capacity to ensure effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore entirely natural that they have opposed their accession to the Schengen area.
Allowing it now means opening the door to transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is immense migratory pressure from Turkey.
Many are the reasons, most opposed, that Europe cannot ignore.
I therefore ask to know what the intentions are of those who have omitted to provide advice on this sensitive matter, which in my opinion has been handled so far with superficiality.
sufficiency and without taking into account the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in matters of security and international crime.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, we all know how important the role played by the International Criminal Court is, which deals with prosecuting the perpetrators of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times, the Court has increasingly become the target of unjust political attacks.
Its arrest warrants have often been ignored, and for this reason the current budget is not proportional to the efforts and commitment exerted.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text approved today because it is the task of the European Union to take all political, diplomatic, and logistical actions to support the Court and ensure its independence and proper and effective functioning.
Madam President, honorable colleagues, phosphates present in domestic washing machine detergents end up in water systems, rivers, streams, and European lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration in the reproduction of various forms of life. Consequently, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in phosphorus levels in an aquatic environment.
This excessive algae growth deprives other living organisms of oxygen, can also produce toxins by destroying aquatic plant species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the text adopted today because, in order to purify Europe's water resources, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that is released into the waters of our continent.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, the European Union has produced an enormous quantity of laws and regulations to construct European law and has created the European area known as the stock plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use made of it by citizens, which is numerically very low in percentage terms.

On the other hand, national judges, the legal professionals of individual states, have grown up within the legal system of their own country and have received predominant training in this set of laws.
while we believe that the true European judge is the national judge who changes their mindset and immerses themselves in the knowledge of European law.

Therefore, before discussing training, we must first focus on effectively communicating with citizens and legal professionals. This will enable them to become advocates for this significant innovation and foster a desire to harness the benefits of this new right.

But above all, it is a bottom-up movement that must be created in in-service training. One cannot teach as if to schoolchildren in the judicial training of adult and highly professionally qualified individuals.

One must foster curiosity in addressing one's own cases, in connecting with other colleagues, and in finding solutions, given that today common law and civil law are converging and are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the real point. In our proposals, and I am glad that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects in our convention, we are calling for a bottom-up reversal of trend, more legal studies, which is judicial training.

There is an example in the Netherlands called Euinfra, which is very interesting. It is a network of responsible individuals in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage magistrates to engage with it.
Here is the essence of our project: we hope to receive the full support of the committee.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I would like to express my deepest appreciation for the work done by my colleague Gigol in this initiative report. I also recall that together with him and others, we actively participate in the Social Economy Intergroup of this Parliament.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, not just one of many policies, but a policy that defines our project itself.

At this time, given the attacks, also linked to the need for cuts in public spending, etc., we still strongly defend this priority. We know that it can be an updated, modified social model, but we also believe that it should be maintained, protected, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

Therefore, I believe that within this same vision, we must also enhance the economic entities that engage in business, that produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, which play a very specific role in the so-called European social economy.

It is reaffirmed that production can be carried out, good things can be done, and efficiency can be achieved, even without profit as the objective. Instead, for example, the goals might be employment, welfare, the valorization of labor, and contributing to the life of the local community.

This is why, Mr. President, I conclude by emphasizing that Europe should provide the necessary tools for an effective policy and create a good statute, not the current inadequate one, but a robust statute for cooperatives, which could be a way to support this crucial sector.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the role of the cooperative movement has always been significant in building a more balanced and fair economic dimension.

At this moment, as we are going through one of the most severe economic and social crises since the postwar period, the function of cooperative societies becomes crucial. Indeed, it is evident that the role of these organizations can significantly contribute to overcoming the difficulties we are facing.
A robust development of the cooperative dimension within the economy has consequently led to an increase in employment, more qualified jobs, and a more balanced redistribution of produced wealth.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary that there be a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must be done by helping and not creating bureaucratic obstacles.
For this reason, I voted in favor of this re-launch and I hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to address the issues mentioned.

the employment prospects of millions of European unemployed do not depend on the limping assistance offered by the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. The data collected highlight that most beneficiaries of the fund are unable to find new employment, while the more fortunate are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts, sometimes as short as six months.
In many cases, unemployed individuals give up on this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The fig leaf is not a solution and does not plug the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously with too much lightness by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of now structural unemployment, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose fierce competition is the primary cause of the failures of our businesses.
