Sir, Commissioner, today you have asked Europe for a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most staunch supporters of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for the exercise of this role.
Without a greater Europeanization of national strategies, also in terms of job protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The automotive crisis is not solely about overproduction capacity and the dramatic loss of jobs.
But the crisis now appears structural and concerns the very destiny of the automobile and the product, as we know them today.
We want to keep the automotive industry in Europe and we do not want to lose the existing expertise, the know-how, and the professional skills.
We therefore call for the launch of a major restructuring and revitalization project, and that it not be done in a short timeframe because the costs are proportional to the time required.
Restructuring cannot be solely the result of fragmented national decisions or individual company initiatives.
It is necessary to at least attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing together the stakeholders through social dialogue.
The trade unions and the governments of individual countries should offer support in the form of research, innovation, human capital training, retraining, and the necessary funds.
I know this will be a hard blow because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I believe that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective community impulse and guidance to jointly face the increasingly aggressive global market.
The energy crisis has exacted and continues to exact a very high price from all employment, affecting thousands of precarious, stable, and temporary workers, who are numerous in this sector.
The major steel groups are increasingly turning towards the Far East or the American continent, posing a great question about the direction of our development model.
I firmly believe that Europe must reclaim the idea that a manufacturing system like ours requires robust core productions capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector's role as a stable steel industry; we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to halt industrial decline.

And I believe that we need to move away from a dualism that has not been fully explored here tonight, but which is often felt in discussions on this sector—a dualism between environmentalists and workers' advocates. This is mistaken because it does not allow us to see a future perspective.
An industry that considers steelmaking as an integral part requires advanced production systems, well-balanced concrete solutions that safeguard diverse interests and needs.

Therefore, there is a strong European projectuality that aims for sustainability, on which, in my opinion, we must not turn back, as it represents a true added value with which we want to compete in the world, supporting investments as has been done.

more parts, new technologies, new processes, the upgrading of facilities, for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, in fact starting with energy resources and also focusing on the research of new and different materials.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, as we have recalled in this Chamber, next December, the United Nations agency dedicated to communication and information technologies will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We cannot forget, and I am pleased with Commissioner Tajani's words, the work that has been done so far, which cannot be called into question. Nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed.

a supranational structure like the IITU, of which we know that hundreds of states from around the world are part, and many of which are known for issues related to democracy, transparency, and freedom of expression.
Therefore, it is not incorrect to believe that the pillars of the internet—that is, freedom, participation, openness, and innovation—are in danger.
Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the internet and, above all, the role that the internet can play in boosting economic growth, but also to ensure opportunities for all.
I therefore hope that the Commission works towards the goal of a united Europe, with Dubai, speaking with one voice.

Many are the controversial proposals presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, in particular those that foresee changes to the governance of the internet that call into question the neutrality of the network, with negative consequences for consumers.
At risk is therefore the freedom of the internet, or more precisely, the freedom of expression and data protection.
As some states have proposed, this would indeed allow a government to snoop not only on the communications of its own citizens, but also on data traversing its networks.
The step from here to limiting freedom of expression to censorship is extremely short, and therefore I believe it to be in contradiction with the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, I have expressed my support for the text presented by my colleague. In particular, I agree with the rapporteur in emphasizing the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore deem it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training on jurisdiction for judicial and administrative legal authorities, as well as for legal professionals.
All initiatives in this field should be intensified to fully realize the concept of the Union based on the rule of law.

Madam President, honorable colleagues, in recent years, the extraction of unconventional hydrocarbons, including shale gas and oil, has brought about an unprecedented transformation in global energy markets.
Europe, already facing such situations and aiming to reduce its dependence on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore need to rely on its potential reserves of gas and lignite.
In this regard, some member states have already authorized the exploration for shale gas and are preparing for the extraction phase should a discovery permit it.
In a context such as this, it becomes necessary to monitor the regulations concerning the extraction of shale gas within the borders of the Union in order to assess the effects of its production.
Economic extraction methods, without a doubt valid, do not pose environmental problems due to the potential release of harmful substances into groundwater or the atmosphere.
Thank you, Mr. President. I believe that today's occasion should be used to objectively discuss the significant agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country as it pertains to the stability and strategic future of Central Asia, and it is undeniably an important economic and commercial part of the European Union.
This is a country that has already initiated a process of economic reform and also a democratic process, but which still needs to commit significantly to bring these processes to full completion.

It is, however, a country that, with this goal in mind, persists in showing itself ready for new and stronger reforms, and I believe that this is precisely the task of the European Union to accompany them.

European, and for this reason I am certain that the signing of this enhanced agreement will allow for progress because its approval will strengthen an already solid and productive relationship and ensure constant assistance from the European Union.

I remain convinced, and I believe this should have been emphasized even more in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that the improvement of progress towards democracy, human rights, and the rule of law should be accompanied by a renewed, open, and constructive reciprocal commitment.

Our goal should not be to take a negative stance toward these other countries in the face of the immediate lack of progress on changes. Our goal must be to support these countries' efforts to achieve the objective of respecting human rights principles as well.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues, while wishing to thank the rapporteurs for the reports we will vote on tomorrow, I would like to make a brief comment on the issue of spinning and I associate myself with what I heard tonight as a unanimous voice from all colleagues.
I would like to focus on artisanal fishing and the ferrule relationship, which I greet and for which I offer my congratulations.
I wanted to say that the past Common Fisheries Policy has only contributed to increasing the gap between the institutions regulating fishing and its true actors, namely fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now, in Europe the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing has disadvantaged those who have always understood fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

It is thus that the conviction dries up that the line taken by the European Commission was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the reasons of thousands of fishermen who for a couple of

For decades, they have operated according to rules that are related to the conservation of the ecosystem, with which I can only agree, but which have never preserved the work activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This initial own-initiative report sends a strong signal to the Commission, which could result in practical measures to the benefit of the fisheries microeconomy.
The report indeed highlights a series of advantages in allocating a minimum amount to small-scale fishing from the European Fund.
We must encourage projects with integrated solutions that benefit the entire coastal community, and moreover, Commissioner, it will be indispensable to encourage young people's access.

We have discussed this several times in the Committee, because otherwise, the fishing industry will likely die not only due to the depletion of the seas and fish stocks but also because young people are no longer entering this sector.
This report serves as an opportunity to incorporate training and introductory moments for young people who wish to enter the sector.

The first criticism is that at the budget level, we are far from being aligned, let alone in terms of growth and employment investments; we are still at the 2008 budget level. It must be acknowledged, however, that regarding heading 1a, the proposed draft completely overturns the scandalous Cypriot hypothesis.
It is true that here the role of the budget is recognized as an indispensable driver of growth in certain sectors, in addition to national budgets.

But let it be clear that growth and innovation must not come at the expense of other sectors, which are also part of growth and job creation, such as cohesion policy. And also, dear colleagues, the agricultural policy, which has increased employment and is increasingly oriented towards innovation and territorial protection.
Grove Jobs is about culture, training, transnational networks, CEF, and also solidarity and international development, human rights worldwide, and our contribution to the Millennium Goals.

Before us, unfortunately, is the usual spectacle of the Council: no vision, no leadership, a babble of conflicting and competing national interests, an inextricable knot of vetoes, expectations, and general discontent.
Europe, unfortunately, is the great absentee.
Mr. President, honorable colleagues, shark finning is an environmentally unacceptable practice as it threatens the sustainability of certain shark species, which are subjected to this brutal method.
social and economic, as it involves the waste of a food product with commercial value, as well as from an ethical standpoint, as it demonstrates a complete lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been banned since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating the exemption to the prohibition on the removal of shark fins on board Union fishing vessels.

This proposal, by further ensuring that sharks receive the protection they need, will also enable the European Union to actively contribute to the ongoing global effort to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world.
